text:
```mkdir("foo")
touch.(["foo/bar", "foo/baz"])
mv("foo", "..") # fails, asks for `force=true`
mv("foo", "../foo")```
is there a `mv` that doesn't require me to add the `foo` at the end, but implicitly to just move the whole dir? maybe like `mvdir`

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

Success, it has been cross posted <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/56628| to Discourse>. Keep and eye out on Discourse for responses and please add an answer there once you are satisfied with the solution so others can benefit as well. Happy debugging!

frankly, the fact that shell's `mv` has a different behaviour depending on whether the target is an existing directory or not is a source of lots of issues,  I much prefer being explicit, as julia's `mv` requires

text: I agree with you, which is why I think a `mvdir` would be good. The functionality is still useful. It's just too opaque with shell

text:
It does that third command that I posted above, but checks that there is no existing directory in argument 2 that has argument 1's name.
The use case is otherwise I need to loop over each file and move it individually.
